description:
Imagine a time when people were genuinely enthusiastic for a gleaming white future like an endless toothpaste ad. So when was that? Even further back maybe, around 1964. Tomorrowland's early scenes include a boy, the kind who can invent a jetpack, turning up at the snazzy 60s world's fair where he gets an extraordinary glimpse of a dazzling future. Fast-forward a few decades and in the mundane doom-laden present, that same boy, grown into George Clooney, meets a young woman with a kind of optimism he once had. And she too has been given a privilege peek of what's to come. But putting that right before it happens is the challenge for Britt Robertson and George Clooney in Tomorrowland, a film that takes its title from the original Disneyland attraction, along the way the narrative hurtles like a fairground ride past 19th century inventors and 1980s Sci-Fi geekery, in a story arc devised by Brad Bird and co-writer Damon Lindelof, the man who led us into the labyrinth of the TV series Lost and the vaulting ambition of Ridley Scott's Prometheus. But the real romance of the future, for this film at least, seems to reside in that first glimpse of 1960's futurology. So I ask Brad Bird if he regarded that decade as a golden age.

"Well, I would challenge the idea that we only represent the 60s in here. There's also amazing futuristic designs from the late 1800s where they imagined a lot of rod iron and airships before, you know, the Wright brothers created airplanes. They thought of these massive balloons that were very fantastically shaped. And that also is a brand of futurism that is still a great image today."
